message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and history suggest ocular trauma and possible corneal abrasion. Fluorescein stain can help diagnose corneal abrasion. Tonometry is used to measure intraocular pressure and not indicated in this case. MRI is not indicated in the initial management of acute ocular trauma. Topical corticosteroids may be used later in management but are not the best initial step.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and history suggest corneal abrasion, which can be confirmed with a fluoresein stain. The other options are not necessary for initial management of corneal abrasion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation suggests a potential corneal abrasion, and the best initial step in management would be to perform a fluorescein stain to assess for any corneal defects. Orbital MRI may be indicated if there is suspicion of a more serious injury such as a foreign body or retrobulbar hematoma, but this is not the best initial step. Tonometry may be done to assess for intraocular pressure, but this will not assess for a corneal defect. Topical corticosteroids may be used for certain eye conditions, but they would not be appropriate until the underlying problem is identified, as they could worsen a corneal abrasion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history and symptoms suggest that he may have a corneal abrasion or ulcer, which can be diagnosed with fluorescein stain. Tonometry and orbital MRI are not appropriate for initial management. Topical corticosteroids are contraindicated in cases of corneal ulcers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a possible corneal abrasion, which can be identified with fluorescein stain. Orbital magnetic resonance imaging and tonometry may be indicated later but not initially. Topical corticosteroids should not be used until a diagnosis is confirmed.

We refer to Wikipedia articles and other medical websites for help. The patient’s symptoms and history suggest that he may have a corneal abrasion or foreign body in his eye. Fluorescein stain is the best initial step in management as it helps identify the presence of corneal abrasions or ulcers. Orbital MRI and tonometry are not needed yet, and topical corticosteroids can actually worsen the condition if an infection or abrasion is present.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a corneal abrasion or ulcer, which can be confirmed by fluorescein staining. Tonometry measures intraocular pressure and is more appropriate for suspected glaucoma. Orbital magnetic resonance imaging is not necessary at this point. Topical corticosteroids should not be used until corneal ulcer or infection have been ruled out.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient reported sudden onset of pain in the right eye while drilling, symptoms suggestive of corneal abrasion. The best initial step in management is to perform fluorescein stain to confirm the diagnosis and assess the extent of the injury. Orbital MRI and tonometry are not indicated in this case, and topical corticosteroids should not be used until the diagnosis is confirmed.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a corneal injury or abrasion, which could be confirmed with a fluorescein stain. Tonometry measures intraocular pressure and is not the best initial step in this case. Orbital MRI is not necessary at this time. Topical corticosteroids are not recommended until the diagnosis is confirmed.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and history suggest a possible corneal abrasion or foreign body in the eye, and the best initial step in management is to perform a fluorescein stain to assess for corneal abrasion. Orbital magnetic resonance imaging can be considered if there is suspicion for orbital fracture or other more serious ocular pathology. Tonometry is used to measure intraocular pressure and is not necessary in this case. Topical corticosteroids are not indicated until after further evaluation and diagnosis have been made.
